results.title: China: times of silk and gold (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Michael Gill and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Professor William Watson, Professor of Chinese Art and Archaeology at the University of London, and Magnus Magnusson continue their journey across modern China, visiting one of the world’s great Buddhist shrines; the caves at Lyang; Sian, the ancient capital; and the tomb of a T’ang princess who died in 701 AD In the Forbidden City of Kubblah Khan in Peking, a remarkable clock is discovered - a present to the Emperor from Britain’s first trade mission in the 18th century.

results.title: China: times of jade and bronze (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: British Broadcasting Corporation and Michael Gill
results.brief_description: In 1973 an exhibition of Chinese art was presented at the Royal Academy in London. Many of the prize pieces appear in this film, which evolves into an extensive journey through modern China to visit many of the sites from which the treasures came, putting them into the context of place and history. With William Watson and Magnus Magnusson. Museum sequences directed by Ray Sutcliffe, photographed by Phil Meheux.

results.title: China: land and the people
results.brief_description: Discusses the similarities and differences in climate, in topography, and in crops of North and South China. Explains that the population of China is greater than that of any other country. Emphasises the importance of agriculture to the Chinese and explains that the 20th century has brought a shift towards industrialisation.

results.title: China: coming of the west
results.creator_credit: Wan-go Wen and China Institute in America
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “Chinese History”.
Highlights the confrontation between the ideas and scientific knowledge of modern western civilization and ancient Chinese civilization from the 15th to 20th century. Provides historical background to the early influence of the Jesuit missionaries in feudal China, the 19th century trade treaties of industrial societies such as Britain and America. Colonisation by Japan and Russia in early 20th century is also discussed. Includes archival film including the establishment of the Republic of China in 1912.

results.title: China: changes from within (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Focuses on the manifestations of social economic and political changes that are taking place in China. These changes will take place over a long time, however the atmosphere which has allowed them is evidence of a trend towards a more ‘democratic socialism’.

results.title: China. Part 3. Life in the city
results.brief_description: Shows daily life in Peking, including scenes of schooling, shopping, religious ceremonies, and construction of new blocks of flats and a causeway. Describes the emphasis placed on health and fitness. Edited version of “China!”.

results.title: China. Part 2. Life in the country
results.brief_description: Reveals China as a land of contrasts. Shows sheep herding in the Sunkiang province, terraced hillsides planted with rice in the more temperate areas, inland lakes and rivers which provide fish, life in country towns, and harvesting activities. Edited from “China!”.

results.title: China. Part 1. History and culture
results.brief_description: Descibes China’s early history, the war with Japan, the revolution and rise of communism. Shows modern industry and transport, the city of Shanghai, Chinese theatre, story telling and musical performances. Edited from the feature documentary ‘China!’

results.title: China!
results.creator_credit: Felix Greene and Dateline Film Productions
results.brief_description: Felix Greene spent several months and travelled over 15,000 miles throughout China to make this visual report on the day-to-day life of the Chinese people. Covers agriculture and industry in various parts of the country and discusses the political situation. Also features aspects of Chinese culture and social customs. Contains b&w archival footage. Music recorded in China by Felix Greene with the Peking Symphony Orchestra conducted by Li Teh-Lun.
